The fire has burned a total of 91,579.51 hectares (ha) in Spain until August 17 in the absence of including the area of large forest fires that have occurred in Castilla y León and Galicia, according to data from the Ministry for Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge (MITECO) to which Europa Press has had access.


Based on data from the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus, Ecological Transition estimates that the total number of hectares affected in Spain by forest fires in progress amounts to 295,579.51: to the 91,579.51 hectares provided by the Autonomous Communities should be added 204,000 from the fires in Castilla y León and Galicia.
In a matter of a week -- the latest information update is from August 10 -- 160,000 hectares would have been burned. If the estimates with Copernicus data are confirmed, 2025 would be the worst year of the entire decade in terms of burned area: with 295,579.51 hectares it would have surpassed the 251,185.11 that had already burned in the same period of 2022.
With figures up to August 17 and in the absence of adding those of these two communities, there have been a total of 55 major forest fires in the country, that is, fires that have affected more than 500 hectares, far from the average of the decade until 2025 (16) and from the data of 2022, when up to this time of the year there had already been 54 major forest fires.

Mexicali, BC., More than 1,600 hectares of vegetation have been affected by a forest fire in the San Pedro Mártir complex in the municipality of Ensenada, which started last August 8.


The Coordination of Civil Protection of Baja California and the National Forestry Commission (Conafor) indicated that the sector with the greatest damage is Santa Rosa, where the flames have consumed 1,100 hectares and in which the conflagration is 30 percent controlled and 20 percent liquidated.
Another open point is La Tasajera 2, with 150 hectares ruined, which yesterday was at 70 percent control and 60 percent liquidation. The branches totally under control are La Encantada, where 401 hectares were damaged, and La Tasajera 1, with 16 hectares.
To contain the fire, firebreaks were opened, containment and liquidation work is being carried out, as well as chainsaw sanitation work on trees and cooling of hot spots.
State and Conaforfor authorities said that two airplanes dropped water on the fire 25 times between Wednesday and Thursday. One hundred volunteer brigadiers, government entities and ranches in the region are participating in the fire containment efforts.
Access to the park is limited
Access to San Pedro Mártir National Park was limited as a preventive measure, and they urged the population not to enter the area, to respect the temporary closures and to heed the indications of the authorities. They also requested that if smoke or flames are detected, to report immediately to the emergency number 911 to address the situation.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-8450-00000-00Alert. Extreme fire risk in Cordoba: reasons, recommendations and where to call for emergencies.2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisAlert. Extreme fire risk in Cordoba: reasons, recommendations and where to call for emergencies.


The Secretariat of Climate Risk Management, Catastrophe and Civil Protection reminds that due to the current and predicted weather conditions, until next Sunday the probability of forest fires throughout the provincial territory will be extreme.


According to the report, this is due to favorable weather conditions for the development of fire outbreaks, such as the increase of temperature, the reduction of relative humidity levels, and mainly due to the increase of wind gusts that could reach up to 60 km/h.
Under these conditions, it is recommended to reinforce preventive control measures.
The spokesman of the agency, Roberto Schreiner, also reminded that "it is forbidden to make fire in the whole territory of the province of Córdoba, except in permitted places, and any activity that could generate a forest fire".
In case of fire, call to:
State of environmental alert due to risk of fires in Córdoba.
Since June 2, a state of environmental alert for fire risk has been in force in Córdoba throughout the province, until December 31 of the current year.
The period of the year when the risk of forest fires is greatest begins with the end of autumn and the beginning of winter after the first frosts, since low temperatures and frosts dry out the vegetation, which becomes highly combustible material, especially in valleys and mountain ranges.
The provincial decree that decreed the state of environmental alert expressly prohibits "the lighting of any type of fire and any activity that may lead to the start of fires".

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-KBG3-RS5V-T01T-00000-00Wildfire season on track to be among worst2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSWildfire season on track to be among worstCarl Clutchey, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Chronicle-Journal

Thunder Bay residents and those who live near the city can breathe deeply with confidence. After a hot summer often characterized by smoky skies, the nearest wildfire currently burning in relation to Thunder Bay is 360 kilometres to the northwest, according to the agency that keeps tabs on fires across the province. "Currently, there are no active wildland fires near Thunder Bay or in the Thunder Bay fire management area," Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) regional spokeswoman Alison Bezubiak said on Wednesday.

As of early Wednesday, there were 25 active wildland fires in Northwestern Ontario, with four of those classified as under control. The rest were being observed, Bezubiak said. Rain is in the forecast for Thunder Bay for the remainder of this week due to a lingering low-pressure system, but amounts are expected to be spotty, said Environment Canada meteorologist Steven Flisfeder. Wednesday was to be "the worst of it," Flisfeder said. "By Sunday, most of the (low-pressure system) will have cleared out." Thunder Bay experienced a remarkably dry August. According to Environment Canada, the city's airport received just nearly 39 millimetres of rain in that month, almost 50 mm less than normal. "Toward the end of July and early August, there was a 12-day stretch when there was no rainfall," Flisfeder noted. July was compensatory overall, with nearly 131 mm falling on the city compared to the long-term average of 89 mm. After the wet July, area farmers appreciated the heat to accelerate crop growth. An Environment Canada overview for August reported that the month "was drier than normal for most regions, especially in central and eastern portions of southern Ontario as well as the northeast." "The Sault Ste. Marie area was a noticeable exception, recording around 190 per cent of its monthly normal (rainfall) from systems that crossed both the south and north of the province," the report added. Meanwhile, Ontario's current wildfire season remains on track to be one of the worst in memory. As of Wednesday, just over 5,900 square kilometres of land has been burned across the province, about three times the long-term average for the same period, according to AFFES data. The bulk of the land burned has been in Northwestern Ontario.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRHB-X2KN-00000-00UN warns that wildfires degrade global air quality2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisUN warns that wildfires degrade global air quality


Mexico City -Forest firesrelease a "toxic mix" of pollutants that can deteriorate air quality thousands of kilometers away, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said Friday, pointing to a notable anomaly in the Amazon in 2024.


This UN agency explained that air quality is intimately related to climate change and that both problems must be addressed together.
Fires in the Amazon, Canada and Siberia have provided information on how air quality can be affected on a large scale, the WMO stressed in its fifth annual bulletin on air quality and climate.
Climate change and air pollution know no national boundaries, as evidenced by intense heat and drought fueling wildfires and degrading air quality for millions of people," saidWMO Deputy Secretary-General Ko Barrett.
In examining the interaction between air quality and climate, the WMO highlighted the role of microscopic particles called aerosols in these fires, the formation of winter fog, emissions from shipping and urban pollution.
Particles smaller than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM 2.5) are considered especially harmful because they can penetrate deep into the lungs or cardiovascular system.
While forest fires in 2024 caused above-average PM 2.5 levels in Canada, Siberia and Central Africa, the largest increase in PM 2.5 was recorded in the Amazon, according to the WMO.
The largest anomaly occurred in the Amazon basin as a result of unprecedented forest fires in the western Amazon region and drought-fueled fires in northern South America," the WMO said in a statement.
At a press conference, Lorenzo Labrador, WMO scientist, stressed that "the forest fire season tends to be more severe and prolonged each year due to climate change".
He also pointed out that forest fires on one continent ended up causing atmospheric pollution on another.
That happened last year and also this year. Therefore, air quality degradation is observed on all continents when meteorological conditions are favorable," he emphasized.
As an example, he mentioned the case of the fires in Canada that affected Europe.
These fires essentially produced a toxic mixture of components that pollute the air," he summarized.
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), air pollution causes more than 4.5 million premature deaths each year worldwide and carries significant environmental and economic costs.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DS3-RS08-T06P-00000-00The regions most affected by forest fires: Which are they?2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisThe regions most affected by forest fires: Which are they?


Cusco, Ancash, Puno, Ucayali, Apurimac and Pasco are the departments most affected by forest fires registered so far in 2025 in Peru, informed the National Institute of Civil Defense (Indeci), which stated that so far this year 475 fires have been registered.


According to Indeci, 254 forest fires were reported in August alone, due to dry season conditions, with lower humidity levels, higher solar intensity and strong winds that favor fire propagation.
In recent days, the institution confirmed that a total of six forest fires were extinguished in the districts of Sihuas (Ancash), Iguaín (Ayacucho), Nueva Requena (Ucayali), Mollepata (Cusco), Las Piedras (Madre de Dios) and Cayma (Arequipa). Likewise, another fire was controlled in San Jerónimo (Apurímac), where the flames consumed natural cover without causing damage to the life or health of the population.
Katy Rivera Montalván, Indeci's Risk and Disaster Management specialist, highlighted that the entity, through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), maintains a permanent monitoring and coordinates actions with the Regional, Provincial and District Emergency Operations Centers (COER), as well as with local authorities. This ensures an immediate and coordinated response to large-scale emergencies.
Report immediately
In the event of a forest fire, Rivera stressed that the population should not intervene directly if they do not have the appropriate training and equipment. "The main recommendation is to immediately inform local authorities and first response entities, such as the Volunteer Fire Department (116) and the National Police (105), so that they can activate their protocols," she said.
Likewise, the Indeci representative urged citizens to take preventive measures to reduce the risk of new fires. "It should be avoided to light fires outdoors near forests or plantations, not to burn vegetable waste or bushes, to completely extinguish bonfires or wood stoves, and not to accumulate flammable materials such as straw or wood, which serve as fuel for fire," she recommended.
During an emergency, the population should remain calm and follow the instructions of local authorities and response entities, including Firefighters, National Police, Armed Forces, the National Forestry and Wildlife Service (Serfor) and community brigades.
Finally, Indeci, an entity attached to the Ministry of Defense, emphasizes that responsible and coordinated participation is essential to protect life, ecosystems and reduce the impacts of forest fires in our country.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-SNK3-RSVS-81V1-00000-00Spain's recent heat wave recorded as 'most intense'2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisSpain's recent heat wave recorded as 'most intense'

Spain recorded its "most intense" heat wave during the 16-day period between Aug 3 and 18, the country's meteorological agency Aemet said on Sunday.

"The recent heat wave has been the most intense since records began in Spain," Aemet said on US social media company X.

The agency explained that the temperatures during the recent heat wave on Aug. 3-18 were 4.6 degrees Celsius (8.1 F) above the seasonal average, exceeding July 2022's previous peak of 4.5C (8.1 F).

Aemet said that while the first 20 days of August 2025 marked the warmest Aug. 1-20 period since at least 1961, the Aug. 8-17 stretch was the warmest in Spain since at least 1950.

Temperatures from January to August ranked as the second highest on record, after 2024, the agency added.

Pointing to the growing duration, extent, and intensity of heat waves, Aemet attributed the increase to climate change.

"That four of the five most intense heat waves have occurred since 2019 is not a coincidence. Not every summer will always be warmer than the previous one; however, the trend toward more extreme summers is clear. The keys: adaptation and climate change mitigation," the agency said.

Aemet said temperatures are expected to rise over the next few days, though a possible drop could occur by month's end, as the country continues to battle ongoing wildfires that started in early August.

Although Spain started to see improvements in the fire situation, firefighting efforts continue in the northwest where 15 fires remain active, according to broadcaster RTVE.

Wildfires have scorched over 407,000 hectares (1 million acres) across the country, with Galicia hit hardest at nearly 90,000 hectares (222,000 acres) in recent days, according to the European Forest Fire Information System.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S7Y3-RXG1-G2CN-00000-00Forest fires have affected 45 hectares so far this year2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisForest fires have affected 45 hectares so far this year


Forest fires in Portoviejo have generated a number of concerns in recent months. On Sunday, September 7, two emergencies of this type were recorded almost at the same time.
The first occurred on the road to Manta and the second in the town of Los Mangos. Roberto Montesdeoca, inhabitant of this town, said that he had to throw water when he saw that the fire was gaining ground, until the Fire Department's motor pump arrived.


The fire had started because the vacant lots in the sector had been turned into a garbage dump and had begun to burn. Montesdeoca questioned the lack of control of the area's waste lands, which caused the forest fire.
Gustavo Triviño, who lives in the same neighborhood, agreed that there is a lack of control in the area. "They even dump garbage in the grounds of the former airport," he said.
Firefighters attended forest fires
From July to September, firefighters have attended approximately 19 forest fires in Portoviejo. José Intriago Cedeño, commander in charge of the Portoviejo Fire Department , informed that these months are the ones with the highest incidence of forest fires, due to the fact that many people start burning the undergrowth.
"People who are engaged in agricultural production burn (brush) and sometimes they do not carry out a controlled burning," he said. In the Los Mangos citadel fire, he said that some person would have set fire to the accumulated debris. "Our units from two stations had to be there," he said.
In the fires registered this year, about 45 hectares were affected. These figures coincide with the history of critical seasons that occur between the months of July and October, a time when weather conditions and agricultural practices increase the risks of fire spread.
Intriago emphasized that the parishes most affected by these events are Andrés de Vera, Picoazá and Colón, where historically the highest rates of forest fires are concentrated.
Recent emergencies in critical sectors
One of the most significant fires occurred approximately two weeks ago on the road to Manta, where the fire affected about 14 hectares. The flames quickly spread to both the left and right sides of the road, requiring the mobilization of several response units to put out the fire.
Article 246 of the Código Orgánico Integral Penal establishes penalties of one to three years in prison for those who start fires without authorization. If the event causes the loss of human lives, the penalties can reach 13 to 16 years, although in Portoviejo have not been able to directly identify those responsible for the recent fires, said Intriago.
The commander pointed out that, during emergencies, firefighters must deploy several units and ambulances to prevent decompensation of personnel on duty, which considerably increases operating costs .
He recommended that farmers request training from the firefighters before carrying out any type of agricultural burning. He also called on the public to act responsibly and avoid practices that could trigger emergencies, since the most important thing is to protect the life and health of the population living in the areas affected by forest fires.

Forest fire and air pollution

The state of Assam, known for its lush greenery and rich biodiversity, is now battling incidents of massive forest fires and an invisible yet formidable air pollution. While rising temperature on account of climate change impact and prolonged dry spells increases forest fire risk and vulnerability, rapid urbanization, construction activities and vehicular emissions have painted a grim picture of the city's air quality. Cement dust pollution has emerged as a significant health hazard, leading to chronic respiratory illness, allergies, asthma and bronchitis among the city dwellers. The editorial, 'Community-based forest fire management,' published in your esteemed daily on March 20, has said that the expansion of human settlement closer to forest areas has increased the vulnerability of forest fires, which have engulfed adjacent dwelling houses, public buildings, etc., in the state.

There is a need to focus on planning, building capacity and adding to the inventory of firefighting equipment to ensure that prevention and detection of forest fires remain top priorities. The availability of water sources nearer to the forest fire spots is a strategic advantage for aerial firefighting. Again, Guwahati, the capital city of Assam, is experiencing deteriorating air quality due to severe degradation of air quality in Byrnihat, Guwahati, and other industrial hubs, placing Assam at the centre of a growing environmental crisis. The city is choking on dust and smoke today due to rampant garbage burning, including plastic and polythene waste, which have further compounded the city's air quality woes. So far as forest fire conservation issues are concerned, there is a need for the broader role of communities, sharing of traditional knowledge for forest and nature conservation and departmental scientific measures, which will go a long way in addressing challenges of forest cover loss while reducing vulnerability and improving better response to outbreaks of forest fires. We cannot deny the importance of interstate coordination to improve forest fire management in the state. At the same time, we need citizens' awareness campaigns, combined with robust policy intervention to improve waste management, promote green energy alternatives and strict industrial audits, apart from collaborative, sincere efforts between Assam and Meghalaya through research-driven sustainable solutions to counter the mounting pollution crisis. The removal of the smog veil over the city and the state is the urgent need to provide a healthier life for future generations.

Iqbal Saikia,

Guwahati.

Moon water

There could be more water on the Moon than we thought. Water ice sheets are reportedly present outside the polar regions of the earth's natural satellite, whereas hitherto the general impression was that water was confined to within the polar area. This information has been supplied by the Indian lunar spacecraft Chandrayaan-3, and analysed by the research team in Ahmedabad. Earlier, it was in 2009 that Chandrayaan-1 clearly indicated the presence of water molecules in the polar regions of the moon. These two landmark spacecraft of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) have expanded the overall knowledge on lunar ice deposits.

If water is present beyond polar regions, lunar explorers can traverse further than being confined to the polar areas and utilise the frozen ice resources for oxygen as well. It's good news for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) that is eyeing the south pole of the moon. Even otherwise, extraction of water from ice portends well for future moon explorers. ISRO also aims to search for more water ice for the benefit of all. Splitting water into oxygen and hydrogen for multiple scientific purposes could be one such benefit. These developments in the space should augur well for India's space capabilities. Besides, an ocean of knowledge beckons space students and scientists who are keen to make a mark in the sector. Industries and universities too stand to immensely gain from information sent by the spacecraft.

Dr Ganapathi Bhat

(gbhat13@gmail.com)

Nature's tiny messengers

The theme for this year's World Sparrow Day, celebrated on March 20, is 'A Tribute to Nature's Tiny Messengers', and as we celebrate, let us give a clarion call to raise awareness about the decline in sparrow populations due to environmental degradation and other factors which, if not addressed now, can have these tiny friendly creatures of man and nature get enlisted in the 'extinct creatures list'.

Though environmentalists and bird lovers do take measures to conserve, preserve and protect these agile, lively little birds, there is a steep decline in their population, especially in urban regions. These tiny birds enjoy living alongside human settlements, but in recent years, various factors such as rapid urbanisation, lack of green spaces, the use of chemical compounds in seeds and grains, and environmental changes and noise and sound pollution have resulted in sparrows disappearing at an alarming rate. Though conservation efforts are being done by nature lovers and other agencies, a joint effort by the public is also a must in order to protect and preserve these birds. The theme no doubt aims to restore human affection for sparrows, inspiring and encouraging them to protect nature's little companions.

Awareness campaigns and events and encouraging and including the younger generation to be very much a part of this can enhance protection measures of these birds. Let us be aware that sparrows are vital for the ecosystem, and their absence would lead to disturbance of ecosystems, which affects various plant and wildlife species.

Pradyu Mukund

(pradyumukund22@gmail.com)

A step towards safer travel

I am writing to express my concern about the ongoing construction work in some places of Guwahati, which is causing major problems for the people of the city. The slow pace of construction and the road equipment left on the streets are making travel difficult and unsafe. Many people, including the elderly who have to work for their livelihood, do not feel safe riding or driving, especially at night. Additionally, potholes and damaged pavements are making roads dangerous for pedestrians and vehicles alike. Visually impaired individuals face even greater challenges. They cannot move freely because of the unsafe conditions caused by construction. I urge the government to take immediate action. There should be proper management of construction materials, and authorities must ensure that street lighting is improved, especially around construction zones, to enhance night-time visibility. I hope this issue is taken seriously, and necessary steps are taken for the safety of all residents.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G73-RTR1-620H-00000-00Freedom Takes A Back Seat To Bureaucratic Convenience2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisFreedom Takes A Back Seat To Bureaucratic ConvenienceMarco Navarro-Genie


 
The new pandemic-style rules aren't about stopping forest fires. They're about managing risk to thin public services
When Nova Scotia Premier Tim Houston banned walking in the woods during forestfire season, the justification was simple: safety. Soon after, New Brunswick's Susan Holt followed his lead.
But when Holt defended the ban publicly, she said something revealing-and troubling.


It wasn't about fires at all.
"Me going for a walk in the woods is gonna cause a fire. I can understand why people, uh, think that that's, that's. That's ridiculous. But the reality is, it's not that you might cause a fire, it's that if you're out there walking in the woods and you break your leg, we're not gonna come and get you because we have emergency responders that are out focused on a fire ... And if you take your boat out fishing ... and you capsize, we're not gonna be able to come and help you out because our first responders are focused on an immediate and serious threat ... it's the possibility of diverting emergency resources away from where they are really needed."
Holt's explanation makes one thing clear: this is not a fire-prevention policy. It's a restriction on movement designed to protect the system from hypothetical inconvenience.
You may not be injured, and you may not cause any trouble at all, but if you could, and if the government's resources are busy elsewhere, you can be told to stay home.
The logic is instantly familiar. It's the same reasoning used during COVID lockdowns. Back then, the danger was not that you, specifically, were sick, but that you might be-and that your illness might contribute to hospital strain. "Flatten the curve" was about protecting system capacity, not eliminating disease.
In short, the forest fire bans recycle the same logic-just in a new setting. They make the public responsible for the state's operational shortages. Scarcity is managed not by increasing capacity-more firefighters, more rescue crews-but by reducing the public's freedom to create demand.
It's worth spelling out the underlying assumptions.
First, the state assumes the right to manage your risk-taking. If your actions could, in theory, lead to a call for help at an inconvenient time, the state may prohibit them. This is an inversion of the citizen-government relationship: your life must adjust to the bureaucracy's needs, not the other way around.
Second, it assumes that a shortage of services is your problem to accommodate. Instead of fixing the shortage, the government narrows the range of activities you are allowed to pursue.
Finally, it normalizes restrictions based on hypothetical harm. No incident need occur. The mere possibility is enough. That principle, once accepted, has no natural limit-because all human activity carries possible risk.
These assumptions, once accepted, don't remain isolated.
This is how a pandemic-era mindset migrates into other domains. Once you accept that liberty can be suspended for the sake of "system protection," the list of triggers grows: forest fire season, peak flu season, snowstorms, police shortages, even energy constraints. The extraordinary becomes ordinary, and the temporary becomes policy.
Politically, the appeal is obvious. Limiting freedom is easier than making tough decisions about resources and figuring out efficiencies. Telling citizens they cannot ski in winter because hospitals are busy is cheaper than staffing those hospitals to handle flu patients and broken legs. Restricting public gatherings because police are committed elsewhere is easier than efficiently allocating officers. Framing it as care, "for your safety," softens the edge and keeps pushback low.
But it is a profound change in how governments understand their role.
In the traditional view, the state exists to safeguard liberty and provide the means for citizens to live freely despite risk. In this new model, citizens must live cautiously to ensure the state's ability to function without strain. The system becomes the priority.
Some will dismiss this as a passing irritation, unique to the fire season. But the pandemic proved how quickly "temporary" restrictions can reappear in new forms. The Nova Scotia and New Brunswick bans show that COVID's logic has been internalized by governments across the political spectrum, including those that identify as conservative.
The problem is not that governments sometimes need emergency powers. The problem is that the threshold for using them now appears to include the prospect of inconvenience to the system.
It is a shift from protecting the public in emergencies to protecting the bureaucracy from strain.
And the cost is not abstract.
Freedom of movement is not a minor liberty. It is a baseline for everything else-for work, for association, for daily life. If it can be revoked because you might twist your ankle while first responders are busy, it can be revoked for almost anything.
The fire season will end. But unless the logic behind these bans is rejected, the season for restrictions will not.
The next emergency-real or perceived-will bring the same refrain: stay home, for the sake of the system. And each time, the public will be expected to accept that liberty is conditional, rationed out only when the government finds it convenient.
That is not the Canadian tradition. That is not how free societies work. And it will only stop when citizens insist that the system exists for them-not the other way around.

Between August 1 and 21, forest fires devastated a total of 362,473 hectares in Spain, according to official data from the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (Effis). This figure represents an environmental alarm that threatens biodiversity, ecosystems and the survival of numerous protected species.


The flames hit these three autonomous communities particularly hard:
Other areas also suffered significant damage, although on a smaller scale, such as Asturias (2,405 hectares), Madrid (2,338 hectares), along with scattered territories in Andalusia, Navarra and Castilla-La Mancha.
Damage to protected ecosystems and vulnerable species
97% of the hectares affected correspond to large forest fires that damaged wooded areas and protected natural spaces. Approximately 140 thousand hectares of wooded areas were consumed and 160 thousand hectares of territories belonging to Protected Natural Spaces and the Natura 2000 Network suffered severe damage.
The effect on fauna is also profound, with some 395 endangered or specially protected species affected, including the Lespre List:
A European summer with record forest fires
The crisis in Spain is part of a worrying trend across the European Union. In 2025 it registered an all-time record of more than one million hectares burned by fires, the highest figure since records began in 2006, according to Effis.
This rate exceeds the previous historical series of 2017, when fires ravaged 988,524 hectares, with Portugal as the hardest hit. In 2025, the impact is even more extensive and involves risks for multiple southern European countries, with Spain and Portugal leading the way.
Faced with this emergency, the Spanish government has reinforced the fight against the fire, including the incorporation of 500 soldiers to support the firefighting efforts. The third vice-president and Minister for Ecological Transition, Sara Agesen Muñoz, stated in the Senate the need for a deep analysis and a joint work to face the problem both in the immediate and in the long term.

urn:contentItem:6G0V-G1S3-RSX1-251K-00000-00New Findings Reported from King Khalid University Describe Advances in Physics (Assessment of Forest Fire Impact and Vegetation Recovery in the Ghalahmah Mountains, Saudi Arabia)2025-06-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisPHYSICSNew Findings Reported from King Khalid University Describe Advances in Physics (Assessment of Forest Fire Impact and Vegetation Recovery in the Ghalahmah Mountains, Saudi Arabia)


2025 JUN 09 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- New study results on physics have been published. According to news originating from Abha, Saudi Arabia, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Forest fires are a critical ecological disturbance that significantly impact vegetation dynamics, biodiversity, and ecosystem services. This study investigates the impacts of forest fires in the Ghalahmah Mountains, Saudi Arabia, using remote sensing data and fire impact models to assess fire severity, environmental drivers, and post-fire vegetation recovery."


Funders for this research include King Khalid University And The Ministry of Education in The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from King Khalid University: "The research integrates Landsat 8, Sentinel-2, and DEM data to analyze the spatial extent and severity of a 2020 fire event using the Relativized Burn Ratio (RBR). Results reveal that high-severity burns covered 49.9% of the affected area, with pre-fire vegetation density (NDVI) and moisture (NDWI) identified as key drivers of fire severity through correlation analysis and Random Forest regression. Post-fire vegetation recovery, assessed using NDVI trends from 2021 to 2024, demonstrated varying recovery rates across vegetation types. Medium NDVI areas (0.2-0.3) recovered fastest, with 134.46 hectares exceeding pre-fire conditions by 2024, while high NDVI areas (>0.3) exhibited slower recovery, with 26.55 hectares still recovering. These findings underscore the resilience of grasslands and shrubs compared to dense woody vegetation, which remains vulnerable to high-severity fires. The study advances fire ecology research by combining multi-source remote sensing data and machine learning techniques to provide a comprehensive understanding of fire impacts and recovery processes in semi-arid mountainous regions."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results suggest valuable insights for sustainable land management and conservation, emphasizing the need for targeted fuel management and protection of ecologically sensitive areas. This research contributes to the broader understanding of fire ecology and supports efforts to post-fire management."
For more information on this research see: Assessment of Forest Fire Impact and Vegetation Recovery in the Ghalahmah Mountains, Saudi Arabia. Fire, 2025,8(5):172. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8050172.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Rahmah Al-Qthanin, Department of Biology, College of Science, King Khalid University, Abha 61413, Saudi Arabia. Additional authors for this research include Rahaf Aseeri.

FULL TEXT

Madrid, Aug 27 (EFE).- Spain on Wednesday was still battling 14 active wildfires, most of them at Operational Level 2, although authorities said that favorable weather would make the next 48 hours crucial in bringing the flames under control.

Civil Protection and Emergencies director Virginia Barcones said that 35,656 people had been evacuated since the current wave of fires began on Aug. 8.

She said that despite the opportunity, strong winds remained the main obstacle to firefighting efforts.

The blazes were concentrated in Galicia, Castile and Leon, and Asturias, while King Felipe VI and Queen Letizia began touring affected areas to meet with residents impacted by the disaster.

The State Meteorological Agency (Aemet) warned that wildfire risk remained "very high or extreme" in western and southern Spain, although falling temperatures and rising humidity could aid firefighting efforts.

According to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), some 272 fires this year had destroyed more than 413,800 hectares, making this the worst wildfire season in Spain so far this century.

In Galicia, flames in Ourense and Lugo caused repeated road closures since Tuesday.

In Asturias, progress was made in containing three fires, although winds continued to fan the flames. Several villages remained evacuated after a blaze spread rapidly on Tuesday, but firefighters managed to secure many areas overnight.

Castile and Leon, the hardest-hit region, was still facing nine active fires, but the conditions there were improving.

Since Aug. 10, aerial firefighting units flew between 260 and 280 hours daily, in some cases reaching peaks of 300 hours, an unprecedented amount of time, officials said. EFE

The Nature Protection Service (SEPRONA) of the Command of the Civil Guard of A Coruña, in collaboration with other units of the Command, has arrested a resident of Carballo as the alleged perpetrator of 11 crimes of forest fire.


The Armed Institute reports that the arrest has occurred in the framework of the exploitation phase of the Monte Fumeiro operation, which began as a result of the fire occurred on July 10 in the parish of Entrecruces. In the course of this operation, 10 other forest fires occurred on July 31 and on August 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 16, 17, 18 and 19 in the same area.
The fires were of little importance due to the rapid intervention of the fire-fighting services, which required a permanent surveillance of the area and the withdrawal of personnel from other areas. This, as indicated by the Guardia Civil, has a "consequent repercussion" in the current context of large fires, where numerous troops are mobilized.
Following the investigation work carried out, the Civil Guards were able to identify the alleged perpetrator of the offenses. Once the identity was known, the Civil Guard proceeded to arrest her for allegedly causing a total of 11 forest fires. The detainee, along with the actions carried out, was placed at the disposal of the Court of Instruction number 3 of Carballo.
The Civil Guard stresses that this type of behavior puts at serious risk not only the natural heritage, but also the safety of neighbors and firefighting operations themselves, in a summer marked by extreme temperatures and the proliferation of fires in Galicia.

Discover the Enchanting, Eco-Conscious Epic That's Captivating Readers Young and Old

In the dappled light of an ancient forest, where the air hums with life and the earth smells of damp leaves and possibility, a secret civilization has thrived in harmony with nature since the days of cavemen. They are the Crum, a remarkable offshoot of hominidae, standing no taller than thirteen inches, with leaf-green hair, grey-brown skin, and the extraordinary ability to hear the thoughts of the animals they live among. This is the breathtaking world introduced in the new novel, Roo and the World of Crum.



This is not a story of conquest, but of connection. It is a ground-level epic that unfolds in the mossy undergrowth, along babbling creeks, and under the roots of mighty oaks. Readers are invited to don a "shum" (a camouflaging cowl) and step into the shoes of Roo, a young and curious Crum, and his fox companion, Fen. Together, they navigate the wonders and perils of the forest-from forging friendships with a wise old stag and a mischievous raccoon to confronting the terrifying, indiscriminate danger of a forest fire.

Roo and the World of Crum is a masterfully woven tapestry of adventure, heart, and profound respect for the natural world. The story delves deep into the Crum's sustainable way of life: their burrows illuminated by cultivated phosphorescent mushrooms, their leather clothes crafted from respectfully sourced materials, and their solemn rituals that return their departed to the earth under the roots of trees. It's a poignant reminder of our place within the ecosystem, teaching lessons of coexistence, bravery, and compassion without ever feeling like a lesson.

The narrative pulses with the life of the forest floor. You'll feel the smooth gait of a fox beneath you, smell the sweet decay of autumn leaves, and hear the simple, earnest thoughts of the creatures who call the woods home. This is a book that doesn't just tell a story; it immerses you in an ecosystem.

Roo and the World of Crum is more than a book; it's an experience. It's a call to listen more closely to the world around us, to tread a little lighter, and to find magic in the most unexpected places.

Discover the Enchanting, Eco-Conscious Epic That's Captivating Readers Young and Old

In the dappled light of an ancient forest, where the air hums with life and the earth smells of damp leaves and possibility, a secret civilization has thrived in harmony with nature since the days of cavemen. They are the Crum, a remarkable offshoot of hominidae, standing no taller than thirteen inches, with leaf-green hair, grey-brown skin, and the extraordinary ability to hear the thoughts of the animals they live among. This is the breathtaking world introduced in the new novel, Roo and the World of Crum.



This is not a story of conquest, but of connection. It is a ground-level epic that unfolds in the mossy undergrowth, along babbling creeks, and under the roots of mighty oaks. Readers are invited to don a "shum" (a camouflaging cowl) and step into the shoes of Roo, a young and curious Crum, and his fox companion, Fen. Together, they navigate the wonders and perils of the forest-from forging friendships with a wise old stag and a mischievous raccoon to confronting the terrifying, indiscriminate danger of a forest fire.

Roo and the World of Crum is a masterfully woven tapestry of adventure, heart, and profound respect for the natural world. The story delves deep into the Crum's sustainable way of life: their burrows illuminated by cultivated phosphorescent mushrooms, their leather clothes crafted from respectfully sourced materials, and their solemn rituals that return their departed to the earth under the roots of trees. It's a poignant reminder of our place within the ecosystem, teaching lessons of coexistence, bravery, and compassion without ever feeling like a lesson.

The narrative pulses with the life of the forest floor. You'll feel the smooth gait of a fox beneath you, smell the sweet decay of autumn leaves, and hear the simple, earnest thoughts of the creatures who call the woods home. This is a book that doesn't just tell a story; it immerses you in an ecosystem.

Roo and the World of Crum is more than a book; it's an experience. It's a call to listen more closely to the world around us, to tread a little lighter, and to find magic in the most unexpected places.

Roo and the World of Crumis available for purchase in paperback and eBook formats on Amazon.

The president of the National Jury of Elections (JNE), Roberto Burneo, affirmed that the jurisdictional lawsuit that this institution will file against the Judiciary does not intend to generate a confrontation, but to ensure the transparency and predictability of the next electoral processes.


The magistrate explained that the action seeks for the Constitutional Court (TC) to define if the resolutions issued by the JNE in electoral matters are unreviewable and, consequently, cannot be questioned through judicial channels.
"If we want transparent elections, to believe in the electoral system, we have to guarantee that its decisions are the last ones, that they are unreviewable, that they have the guarantee that they are under an independent, technical work and finally based on constitutional principles and due process, but we cannot continue in this debate if, suddenly, any decision (of the JNE) can be questioned", said Burneo in a dialogue with RPP.
The head of the highest electoral body warned that the decision of the Judiciary to order the registration of the Unidad Popular party affects the development of the General Elections of 2026, since an attempt is being made to include a political grouping at a time when the corresponding stage had already ended.
"And not only the stage for them to register and participate, but five or six other electoral milestones after that moment", he specified.
Burneo reminded that in previous processes more than 800 actions of amparo were filed with the same objective of reverting decisions of the JNE and estimated that, in the framework of the next elections, more than 3,000 appeals of this type could be filed, which he considered unsustainable for the electoral organization.
In this context, he insisted that it is up to the Constitutional Tribunal to establish the scope of the JNE's competence and to guarantee clarity regarding the intangibility of its resolutions.
"The Constitutional Court is the competent one in this matter to define the competence and clarity around this issue. This administration seeks that we achieve transparent electoral processes and that we strengthen again the confidence in its electoral system, but one of the ways is guaranteeing the predictability and the majesty of its decisions", he underlined.

When two months of no rain had reduced Nova Scotia to a "tinder box" as Premier Tim Houston put it, he ordered people to stay out of the woods.

Many people accepted the measure, which came into effect in the first week of August, as a necessary way to reduce the risk of a stray spark igniting a blaze that wouldn't be controlled. Others were furious.

"People are effectively prohibited from entering nature for the rest of the summer," read one angry post on Facebook that has been interacted with hundreds of times. But the poster, who has tens of thousands of followers, didn't seem to be in any danger of going anywhere near a Nova Scotian forest, permitted or no.

According to the poster's profile and website, he was born and still works in Belgium, where he offers energetic healing and researches the "true nature of reality" and "conspiracies," which involves posting about largely discredited theories about COVID restrictions and the World Economic Forum.

The post about Nova Scotia continued: "I remember not being allowed to go in the woods during COVID in Belgium for a run," they wrote. "This again is a stepping stone towards a climate lockdown."

The rules have some wiggle room - people can still use their own land, stay in designated campgrounds, and go to the beach - and have generated plenty of debate within Nova Scotia. (Including from one local military veteran who deliberately got himself slapped with an almost $28,000 fine so he could challenge it in court.)

But much of the pushback online is coming from outside the house - and seems driven by something bigger than a desire to go for a walk in the woods.

For many of the accounts speaking out about the forest restrictions, this seems like just the latest social media-enabled arena in which to fight back against what they see as an attack on personal freedom.

Many have a history of protesting COVID restrictions or supporting the "Freedom Convoy" - the trucker protest that snarled Ottawa traffic for weeks - suggesting that the tension between individual rights and collective freedom, battle lines drawn and reinforced during the pandemic, remain deeply etched in how we see the world.

"It is absolutely the case that natural disasters are increasingly politicized. We've seen it with hurricanes, floods, and wildfires in the U.S. and Canada," said Amarnath Amarasingam, an associate professor who studies conspiracy theories and online communities at Queen's University.

When Albertans were forced to flee fire in 2023, convoy-linked influencers claimed it was a cover for "land grabs" or "climate tyranny," he says. After Hurricane Ian in the United States, anti-mandate pages claimed evacuation orders were "FEMA lockdowns," he adds.

The appeal of natural disasters lie in the opportunities they present for reopening COVID-era debates about government overreach and the tension between individual rights and group protection.

"The conspiracy element lies in how these restrictions are interpreted," he wrote in an email.

"Instead of viewing them as temporary, risk-based measures, critics cast them as part of a broader scheme: a 'test run' for authoritarian climate policies," he says.

"This taps into familiar pandemic conspiracies about elites manufacturing crises to normalize control."

One man, a former People's Party of Canada candidate named Jeff Evely, deliberately violated the ban so he could challenge it in court.

As shown in a video he posted to social media, he showed up at a powder blue Department of Natural Resources office in Sydney to notify the staff there of his plan to break the rule - "we still have to suggest that you don't," one responds - before doing a quick walk through the trees and emerging to ask about his ticket.

He received the maximum fine, which, with taxes and fees, worked out to $28,872.

(This wasn't Evely's first attempt to push back, but when he tried to challenge a similar ban in 2023 his case went nowhere, in part because he was never fined and so couldn't prove he was negatively impacted.)

This time, his case has been picked up by the Calgary-based Justice Centre for Constitutional Freedoms, an organization that was heavily involved in challenging pandemic restrictions.

"Perish the thought of where I might be, were it not for the JCCF stepping in to provide my legal defence," Evely wrote on his Facebook page.

Evely is a veteran who retired because of PTSD so he benefits from connecting from nature, but also feels an obligation born of long public service to stand up for others' rights, too, says his lawyer, Marty Moore. But there's also a "significant constitutional angle" which caught the JCCF's eye, he says.

"The idea that you can literally categorically ban people from approximately 75 per cent of the area of the province for months on end, without any tailoring to the actual conditions?" he says. "It definitely raises concerns."

Specifically, he argues that the restrictions don't make sense when, on a given day, fire risk might be lower in some areas, or when other potentially risky activities such as forestry are going ahead.

In an email, a spokesperson for Nova Scotia's Department of Natural Resources said the current conditions are "extremely dangerous," noting that as of the third week of August, over 200 firefighters and volunteers plus a dozen aircraft were currently battling the out-of-control Long Lake fire northwest of Halifax.

The ban needed to be broad, they argue, because most fires in Nova Scotia are human-caused, a category which includes the relatively small number of deliberately set fires but also blazes sparked by vehicles, discarded cigarettes and even broken glass bottles.

"The decision to restrict access to Nova Scotia's wood was not made lightly," the statement reads. "Our teams and experts analyze data on a daily basis to make the best decisions for the protection of Nova Scotians. We continue to see widespread support."

But while Evely is in Nova Scotia, his story has been picked up more widely, including by mainstream news shows. But it's also grist for the mill for an expanding network of digital influencers for whom Canada is a frequent example of progressive mismanagement.

That includes heavyweights like Dr. Drew, who illustrated it as "another example of Canadian government overreach," and Joe Rogan, who, despite thinking this was happening in Saskatchewan, appeared to reference Evely when he mentioned the man who'd been fined as having made a "good 28,000 dollar move."

"There's no wildfires," Rogan said about the forest ban, sounding incredulous, "but they're worried about wildfires." (There were, in fact, wildfires.)

The social media infrastructure nurtured during and after the pandemic is built on finding - and fighting for - your own ideological tribe, says Raywat Deonandan, an epidemiologist and associate professor with the Interdisciplinary School of Health Sciences at the University of Ottawa. It demands new sources of outrage.

"Imagine this happening in 1995, before the internet," he says. "Would we have this problem? I don't think so," he adds.

"There might have been some people who were like, 'Oh, I can't go for a walk, darn. I guess I'll go read a book,' " he adds.

"But now they've been given this licence to be problematic social warriors," he says. "This is a virtue performance for your political tribe members."

Moore, the lawyer for Evely and his $28,872 fine, counters that while Charter rights used to be a fringe idea, largely invoked by people broadcasting some out-there ideas, concepts like liberty and individual freedoms have planted themselves in the Canadian consciousness in the last few years.

"Being a free speech advocate myself, it's fantastic that we have and allow and promote and protect different opinions and perspectives," he says. (He does, however, note that where you get those perspectives matters: "I don't think anyone needs to judge Joe Rogan for mentioning a Canadian story. He has no need to get himself informed," he says. "But as a Nova Scotian or a Canadian, yeah, you should.")

Another group leading the conversation online is the similarly Calgary-based Canadian Constitution Foundation, whose previous work includes advocating for a Mississauga man's semi-wild front lawn and against the city of Whitehorse's now-former ban on "microaggressions" or "disrespectful" attire at council meetings.

The group is "leading the charge against the ban, turning it into a political talking point," says Philip Mai, director of the Social Media Lab at TMU. The petition has nearly 5,000 signatures so far.

Part of what allowed this to spread in this case is the fact that most outsiders don't understand the risks faced by such a small, heavily forested province, locals say.

"Nova Scotia is built differently than the rest of the country," Fred DeLorey, a former national campaign manager for the CPC, wrote in a recent Substack.

There is far less Crown land compared to places like B.C. or Quebec, where the swaths of publicly owned wild spaces act as buffers as fires approach, but those just don't exist in such a small province, he writes.

"The forest here isn't 'out there' beyond the edge of town. Growing up in Antigonish County, I didn't have a back lawn - I had a forest, just metres from my house."

The ban on travelling in the forest isn't overreach, he says, it's "hard-earned wisdom."

urn:contentItem:6GP0-HH33-S0GT-42J9-00000-00Forests don't smoke, political promises die out2025-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisForests don't smoke, political promises die out


The wave of fires has already passed and once the fires are extinguished, the importance of the emptied Spain, of the Spain devastated by the fire has dissipated like smoke. Faced with this reality, experienced wave after wave by those involved in the forestry sector, a large group of experts came to Madrid this week to give voice to a proposal for action to revitalize the rural and forestry world of our country in the face of the sociological challenge of its abandonment and the climate that sets the conditions for the fires to be increasingly intense and dangerous.


Convened by the Pau Costa Foundation, in thePress Association of Madrid, last Wednesday, the experts were talking about the proposals that in 2023 took them some time to reach a consensus. Because they are not on the subject since this summer. Foresters, forestry engineers, researchers, firefighters and ecologists put together what they all agreed that the Spanish forest mass needs so that the political class takes note before the political promises are extinguished, if they have not already done so, with the judicial and parliamentary news on which they feed themselves and the media news.
The experts' warning is clear. What happened this summer will happen again. This is already so serious that it should mobilize the resources of the State -state, autonomous and municipal- to avoid it. But the warning is loud and clear: it will get worse, much worse, especially if no action is taken.
"We are meeting at a particularly critical time for our country. So far in 2025, as you know, more than 400,000 hectares have burned in Spain, far surpassing the 2022 record," said Luis Berbiela, moderator and speaker from the Pau Costa Foundation. "Today, unfortunately, we must recognize with concern that little or nothing of what was agreed upon has been translated into political action. Meanwhile, fires are worsening, our forests and villages are weakening and every summer we return to emergencies that put lives, infrastructure and biodiversity at risk," he said.
The presentation brought together representatives of numerous entities such as the Pau Costa Foundation, the Official College of Forestry Engineers, Greenpeace Spain and WWF, who presented a document with proposals structured in seven priority areas: from the management of forest ecosystems to adaptation to climate change. "We need a loudspeaker, a social and political consensus, and to start respecting and valuing the primary sector. It cannot be that only 0.08% of the national GDP is being invested in management and prevention," denounced Arancha Pérez Oleaga, vice-dean of the Association of Forestry Engineers. "It is time to generate momentum and commit to actively manage our territories."
The situation worsens year after year and long-term planning is more necessary than ever. "Plans, by their concept, are always proactive, never reactive. Getting out of a crisis by starting with a plan is not the best thing to do. You have to arrive at the crisis with the plan made. Therefore, the next crisis will come and we have to have the plan ready," warned Juan Picos, a researcher at the University of Vigo.
Rural communities, on the front line of risk, were another focus. "Climate change is a magnifying glass and a mirror that has come to show us how we have our territory: unmanaged, collapsed with biomass, where we have lost our landscape because the countryside has disappeared," warnedMarta Corella, vice-dean of technical forestry engineers and mayor of Orea. "The first measure must be to politically agree to defend the safety of the people who live in the countryside. That requires sufficient money and planning to protect each rural nucleus."
The experts agreed on the importance of changing the social perception and betting on a culture of the territory. "Forests do not give wifi, but they produce our air, our water and our landscape, that where we go when we are stressed," recalled Ferrán Dalmau, engineer and director of Medi XXI GSA. But his request is also very specific: "We are asking to manage 1% of the national territory per year, which is 280,000 hectares. Fire has already managed 400,000 this year".
In terms of extinction and knowledge, Juan Camaño (Pau Costa Foundation) denounced the total lack of specialized research centers and competence certification systems for those who fight fires. "We do not have a homologated system that guarantees that the people who go to a fire have the necessary skills and knowledge. We are not prepared for the scenarios ahead of us."
Nor is there "a diagnosis of the problem, there is no national forest fire risk analysis, there is no analysis, nor is there a national forest fire risk prediction, it does not exist," said Joaquín Ramírez, forestry engineer and executive director of Tecnosylva. Ramírez envisions a future with more severe and intense fires, driven by land abandonment and climate change. However, he trusts in the knowledge and capacity of the Spanish technical and social community to propose solutions, as long as there is political will and social consensus to apply active and resilient land management measures.
On behalf of Greenpeace, forestry engineer Mónica Parrilla stressed that "95% of fires are caused by humans. Climate change does not cause them, but aggravates extremely dangerous situations. She added that it is essential to comply with regulations and provide resources to rural municipalities to implement prevention and emergency plans.
"We are living through an evident planetary crisis. Nature is becoming less resistant to both human and climate impacts," added Enrique Segovia, director of conservation for WWF Spain.
The message of the press conference was very much directed at political passivity: "The lessons we have learned are just that, something that has happened to us. But learning from the lessons requires us to act, and prevention means acting," said Luis Berbiela. "We cannot get carried away by short-term measures or media impact announcements. What is at stake is the safety of citizens, the preservation of our natural heritage and the sustainability of our future."

The general director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, has declared a "very favorable evolution" of the situation of active fires affecting different Spanish provinces.
In statements to the media after the meeting held by the State Coordination Committee and State Committee for Coordination and Management of the National Civil Protection System (CEDOD) this Saturday, Barcones has reported that there are currently seven active forest fires in the country, one of them in operational situation 1 in Almería (Lubrín) and six in operational situation 2, mainly in Castilla y León, although she has stated that the "battle against the flames is coming to an end".


As for the Igüeña forest fire, Civil Protection has stated that its evolution is favorable and that the work of consolidating the perimeter is progressing "at a good pace". In addition, Barcones added that there are no populations confined to the fire and all the roads closed by this fire have been opened.
The fire in Porto (Zamora), which was shared with the province of Leon and Ourense, the evolution is favorable. "There are only small reproductions easily controllable and continues to secure the perimeter," said Barcones, adding that only expected to remain cut Zamora 103 road in the section that connects San Martin de Castaneda with Laguna de los Peces.
FAVORABLE WEATHER CONDITIONS
"The weather conditions have favored the control of the active outbreaks," said Barcones, who stressed the "very favorable evolution" of the fires in León, Galicia and Asturias, where a progressive recovery of the extinguishing device is expected.
As for weather forecasts, she has indicated that this Saturday conditions remain favorable in the area of large fires, with lighter winds and temperatures above 20 degrees. However, the director of Civil Protection warns of more unfavorable conditions for Sunday in the southeast peninsular, with extreme risk of fires.
Barcones concluded her speech by stating that "the stage of fires is closing", although she recalled that "the war against climate change is still active" and asked not to lower our guard.

Lisbon [Portugal], August 30 (ANI): A 14-year-old boy admitted deliberately starting several wildfires in Portugal by riding to forest areas on a scooter and using matches to start a blaze in an interview with police, EuroNews reported.

Officers believe he may have been responsible for blazes in Seidoes, Ardegão and Arnozela.

"The minor may have acted out of anger and frustration, given his poor school performance and the obvious precariousness of his social relationships," the national criminal police, the Policia Judiciaria, said in a statement, adding that they hadn't ruled out the boy acting as part of a group, as per EuroNews.

Police launched an investigation after wildfires repeatedly began in the same areas.

"During the summer period, these parishes were systematically ravaged by forest fires, sometimes on a daily basis, causing concern among the local population and consuming several hectares of forest," the police statement said, as quoted by EuroNews.

The Braga Judicial Police, which carried out the investigation, handed the case over to the Public Prosecutor's Office, which will then take it to the Family and Children's Court.

By August 20, police had already arrested 52 people on suspicion of arson. The data, compiled by the Lusa news agency, showed most of the arrests were made in August.

Emergency services said that on Friday morning, 97 fires were still burning but most are under control and in the process of being extinguished.

The fire in the municipality of Vinhais is reportedly the only one that is still significantly active and posing a danger. More than 400 firefighters, 140 vehicles and six planes were deployed to the area to tackle the fire on Friday, as per EuroNews.

The blaze, which started on Tuesday morning, is active on three fronts, one of which is difficult to access. But on the other two fronts, "most of its perimeter is under control", a regional commander of the civil protection agency told the local news agency, quoted by EuroNews. (ANI)

WILDFIRES have torched more than a million hectares across the European Union this year, data shows, making 2025 the worst on record.

The data also shows records have been broken for the amount of carbon dioxide and other air pollutants.

This summer's infernos emptied villages and forced farmers to become firefighters as the blazes engulfed four times as much land as the average for the same period in the past two decades.

Data from the European Forest Fire Information System, which goes back to 2003, shows 1,015,024 hectares have burned this year, breaking the record of 988,544 hectares only set in 2017.

The blazes also pumped out 37 million tons of CO2 - roughly as much as the yearly emissions of Portugal - as a heatwave pushed temperatures across much of the Mediterranean and Balkans over 40C. And the hot weather could still go on for weeks.

Cristina Santin Nuno, a fire scientist at the Spanish National Research Council, said perfect wildfire conditions were more common now because of changes in the climate and how people use the land.

She said: "It is sad and scary - my home region is burning right now - but not surprising, really. This is a new reality.

"And the sooner we realise it, and take action to be more resilient to these types of wildfires, the better."

The flames are known to have killed more than a dozen people but scientists say the hidden death toll is likely to be far greater. A study in the Lancet blamed wildfire smoke for 111,000 deaths a year in Europe, including Russia, between 2000 and 2019.

Mark Parrington, of EU air monitoring service Copernicus, said of this year's fires: "The large quantities of smoke - and especially PM2.5 [fine particulates] - released into the atmosphere have resulted in severely degraded air quality."

A year after Canada experienced near-record numbers of tornadoes, we're trending to have a relatively low one, particularly in Ontario, and much lower than what we've experienced in recent years.

David Sillis, director with Western University's Northern Tornadoes Project, said via email the summer so far "has been well below normal as far as tornado activity, particularly in Ontario."

In 2025 (as of Sept. 11), the team has confirmed 64 tornadoes in Canada, including 19 in Ontario, Sillis said.

During all of 2024, there were 129 tornadoes confirmed in Canada and 60 in Ontario. The all-time national record was set in 2022 with 131 confirmed tornadoes.

Last year also experienced the longest tornado season on record, lasting 240 days, with the first tornado reported in Malden Centre, Ont. on March 16 and the last one in Fergus, Ont. on Nov. 10.

The first tornado of 2025 reportedly occurred on April 12 in Rolling Hills, Alta.

Historical tornado data in Canada

Over the last few years, NTP confirmed the following number of tornadoes across Canada:

Based on a 30-year period between 1991 and 2020, the average number of tornadoes per year is 64.9 in Canada and 18.5 in Ontario, Sillis said.

The NTP team is investigating why some years are less active, in terms of tornadoes, than others, with Sillis saying there are many factors involved.

Possible reasons for fewer tornadoes this season

Environment Canada couldn't provide a definitive answer as to why we're experiencing fewer tornadoes this year, but offered a hypothesis.

Meteorologist Steven Flisfeder said there are two possible causes why Ontario, and particularly southern Ontario, are experiencing fewer tornadoes this year.

One is that this summer has been dominated by high-pressure systems, which are typically associated with clear skies.

"That would have the tendency to inhibit any kind of storms, any kind of convection, which would lead to lightning, which would lead to potential thunderstorms, which would lead to potential tornadoes," Flisfeder said.

"That high pressure, which was very strong, very persistent throughout the summer, is a possible reason why there were fewer tornadoes than we normally see in a typical year."

The second possibility is related to all the forest fire smoke we've experienced this year, particularly in June and July.

"There was a lot of smoke in the atmosphere, which has a tendency to reduce solar heating, which would help reduce the potential for thunderstorm initiation as well," Flisfeder said.

This is just a hypothesis, he added, noting a definitive answer would require further research.

Is tornado season over yet? Expert outlook

Sillis expects the number of confirmed tornadoes to climb before the year is out.

The NTP team is still reviewing satellite images from Canada's vast boreal forest, which could turn up more tornadoes from this summer that had not been reported yet due to the area's low population density.

"So, the numbers from this summer will likely go up," he said, and tornado season is likely not over yet.

"I suspect we haven't seen the end of the tornado season in Ontario, or Canada, quite yet. In fact, we've got quite a warm-up in the long-range forecast for southern Ontario, and that typically means higher potential for severe storms," he added.

More information on tornadoes in Canada is available on the NTP website.

By Meredith Woodward King

Geographer contributes to global research examining how rainforest 'buffer' helps curb disease

Indigenous Territories in the Amazon rainforest can help buffer and protect humans from forest fire-related illnesses and, in many cases, animal- and insect-borne diseases, according to a recent study by Clark geographer Florencia Sangermano and her colleagues published in the Nature group journal Communications Earth and Environment.

The study was released just two months before COP30, the annual United Nations climate change conference, to be held Nov. 10-21 in Brazil, one of nine countries in the Amazon region. Clark hopes to send representatives from its newly launched School of Climate, Environment, and Society to COP in Belem.

Drawing upon two decades of data on respiratory and infectious diseases in the region, "the study is the first to evaluate the human health benefits of Indigenous lands throughout the Amazon biome," the authors say, "highlighting the complexity of these relationships in the face of different contexts of landscape structure, the legal status of Indigenous lands and the trade-offs that exist between different diseases."

The Indigenous Territories have "complex relationships" with the landscape beyond their borders the amount of forestland and forest fragmentation that exists in surrounding areas which affects whether human disease spreads, according to the study.

Florencia Sangermano attaches speakers to a raft that was to be carried via drone for ecoacoustics research in the Amazon. She was a member of Team ETH BiodivX, which won a bonus prize in the five-year XPRIZE Rainforest competition.

Covering 4.35 million square miles, the Amazon region is home to 33 million people, 2.7 million of them Indigenous, and tens of millions of plant and wildlife species.

"A growing body of evidence shows that Indigenous-managed lands are largely forest covered, especially when legally held or titled," the authors say. "Indigenous Territories ... contribute to curb deforestation and slow biodiversity loss, underscoring the need to recognize and support Indigenous rights globally."

The study highlights that such "policies supporting Indigenous land rights ... are not only essential for protecting these populations," the authors say, "but can also generate positive outcomes for human health."

The article has drawn attention from around the world, including in The Guardian, India News, U.S. News and World Report, Inside Climate News, Mongabay, and other media outlets.

"Particulate matter emissions due to forest fires, and their related health impacts, transcend national borders," Sangermano, associate professor in Clark's Graduate School of Geography, told The Guardian. "International collaborative frameworks that align forest protection, Indigenous stewardship, and fire mitigation strategies across the Amazon biome are essential."

"Our findings highlight the need for policies supporting Indigenous land rights, which are not only essential for protecting these populations but can also generate positive outcomes for human health."

study by florencia sangermano and co-authors

Over the past five decades, the Amazon has lost millions of acres of rainforest due to human activity, including forest fires used to clear the land for agriculture. The fires release noxious fumes containing fine particulate matter, which can lead to lung cancer, chronic bronchitis, asthma, stroke, and other serious respiratory and cardiovascular health problems, according to Sangermano, who was designated a Kavli Frontiers in Science Fellow by National Academy of Sciences.

In a 2023 study published in Communications Earth and Environment, Sangermano and her colleagues examined similar links between deforestation and threats to human health. Based on 10 years of satellite data compiled and analyzed by Sangermano, the scientists analyzed the effect of PM2.5 particulates the fine particles from forest fires on heart and respiratory diseases and the economic impact of these effects. They found that particulate matter can disperse, affecting people who live up to 310 miles away.

Meanwhile, the 2025 study points out that "land-use change stands as the leading driver for emerging zoonotic infectious diseases. Deforestation alters the niche of vectors, hosts, and pathogens, changing their community composition, behaviors, movements, and spatial distribution, and forcing them to live in closer proximity to humans," the authors say. "Deforestation also leads to fragmentation, altering the configuration of the remaining forest areas."

Sangermano has experience partnering with Indigenous and local people on environmental research in the Amazon. In Brazil, as part of the five-year XPRIZE Rainforest competition, she was a member of the global research team ETH BiodivX that eventually won a $250,000 Bonus Prize in 2024. Her expertise in ecoacoustics, geospatial science, and remote sensing helped inform the environmental insights the team derived from data gathered in the Amazon.

The team, she says, was "very happy to be recognized for the part of the work that we were the most proud of working with the local communities and Indigenous communities."

In addition to her research in the Amazon, Sangermano is studying the connections between rainforest loss in Brazil's Atlantic Forest and rodents' transmission of infectious diseases to humans.

"Healthy biodiversity systems," she says, "have healthy animals and, in turn, healthy humans."

By Zia Weise BRUSSELS - The EU is suffering its worst wildfire season on record, surpassing 1 million hectares burned Thursday. Fires have burned 1,016,000 hectares - an area larger than Cyprus or around a third of the size of Belgium - since January, data from the bloc's European Forest Fire Information System analyzed by POLITICO shows.

This is the first time the EU hits the 1 million hectare milestone since EFFIS started keeping records in 2006. The previous worst wildfire season, in 2017, clocked just below 988,000 hectares. Nearly two-thirds of losses occurred since Aug. 5, when EFFIS showed only 380,000 hectares burned. The vast majority of the fires have occurred in the Iberian Peninsula. Spain accounts for more than 400,000 hectares burned, while in much-smaller Portugal, flames have consumed more than 270,000 hectares - or 3 percent of the country's entire territory. In Spain, where records stretch back to the 1960s, this year is the worst fire season since 1994, according to government data . Both countries have endured searing heat in recent weeks, desiccating forests and turning the peninsula into a tinderbox. Climate change is exacerbating wildfire risk, bringing more frequent and intense heat waves and droughts. But scientists say that the main driver of the catastrophic fires in Spain and Portugal is an overabundance of flammable vegetation on abandoned land and authorities' failure to take preventive measures. Spain's special prosecutor for environmental issues this week opened an investigation into the lack of fire prevention plans. Wildfires also release large amounts of planet-warming carbon dioxide, with the EU on track for a potential new record for fire-related pollution as well, EFFIS data shows.
