WILDFIRES have torched more than a million hectares across the European Union this year, data shows, making 2025 the worst on record.

The data also shows records have been broken for the amount of carbon dioxide and other air pollutants.

This summer's infernos emptied villages and forced farmers to become firefighters as the blazes engulfed four times as much land as the average for the same period in the past two decades.

Data from the European Forest Fire Information System, which goes back to 2003, shows 1,015,024 hectares have burned this year, breaking the record of 988,544 hectares only set in 2017.

The blazes also pumped out 37 million tons of CO2 - roughly as much as the yearly emissions of Portugal - as a heatwave pushed temperatures across much of the Mediterranean and Balkans over 40C. And the hot weather could still go on for weeks.

Cristina Santin Nuno, a fire scientist at the Spanish National Research Council, said perfect wildfire conditions were more common now because of changes in the climate and how people use the land.

She said: "It is sad and scary - my home region is burning right now - but not surprising, really. This is a new reality.

"And the sooner we realise it, and take action to be more resilient to these types of wildfires, the better."

The flames are known to have killed more than a dozen people but scientists say the hidden death toll is likely to be far greater. A study in the Lancet blamed wildfire smoke for 111,000 deaths a year in Europe, including Russia, between 2000 and 2019.

Mark Parrington, of EU air monitoring service Copernicus, said of this year's fires: "The large quantities of smoke - and especially PM2.5 [fine particulates] - released into the atmosphere have resulted in severely degraded air quality."

It's the subject of research by Flinders University's Frontiers of Restoration Ecology (FORE) group.

FORE research assistant Alex Taylor was one of the presenters at an Agritech Meetup South Australia event, held at CodeFish Studio at Thebarton in August.

The meetup explored the product development process of creating agricultural technology, from the research stage to commercialisation.

Firmly in the research stage, soil eco-acoustics could be used to assess the efficacy of pest eradication strategies through shifts in the soundscape pre- and post-pest management intervention.

In agricultural systems, soil biota play a key role, with communities of earthworms, beetles, ants and other organisms all playing a part of improved soil structure, aiding in organic matter decomposition and incorporation, as well as helping with water infiltration.

Mr Taylor, who is part of the FORE team led by Associate Professor Martin Breed, said eco-acoustics could provide another tool to detect and measure the activity of beneficial and pest invertebrates.

"In essence, soil eco-acoustics is a novel approach to monitoring soil health," he said.

Mr Taylor said earthworms were a great example of the importance of soil biota to agriculture.

"Earthworms underpin 6.5 per cent of the world's grain production," he said.

As in situ sensing and instrumentation of agroecosystems becomes increasingly common, it provides an opportunity for eco-acoustic sensors and approaches to be tested on a larger scale.

There is also untapped potential for detecting anthropogenic sounds - those generated by mechanical sources - that could negatively impact soil ecosystems.

By expanding the scope of soil eco-acoustics to include anthropogenic sounds, researchers can better understand how sounds produced by human influences, such as machinery, affect soil biodiversity and health.

This expanded application could better characterise the ecological impacts of human activities, and inform better land-use practices, as well as guide mitigation strategies.

The Internet of Things - a network of physical devices embedded with sensors, software and other technologies to connect and exchange data with other devices and systems over the internet - would play a key role in soil eco-acoustics management.

IoT connectivity allows real-time monitoring, data collection and automated decision-making processes across various industries. An example of this is EdgeFireSmoke++, which provides real-time forest fire detection.

Integrating soil eco-acoustics with IoT would involve connecting acoustic sensors to an IoT network.

This could facilitate real-time data to be transmitted to cloud-based platforms for analysis, enabling more efficient soil health monitoring.

This integration could lead to improved land management practices, early detection and real-time responses to soil health issues, improved efficacy of pest management strategies and a better understanding of soil biodiversity.

urn:contentItem:6GSB-9323-RRPV-G2HN-00000-00Is Canada's tornado season over? Experts say not yet, despite low numbers in Ontario2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:46:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Is Canada's tornado season over? Experts say not yet, despite low numbers in OntarioDominik Kurek

A year after Canada experienced near-record numbers of tornadoes, we're trending to have a relatively low one, particularly in Ontario, and much lower than what we've experienced in recent years.

David Sillis, director with Western University's Northern Tornadoes Project, said via email the summer so far "has been well below normal as far as tornado activity, particularly in Ontario."

In 2025 (as of Sept. 11), the team has confirmed 64 tornadoes in Canada, including 19 in Ontario, Sillis said.

During all of 2024, there were 129 tornadoes confirmed in Canada and 60 in Ontario. The all-time national record was set in 2022 with 131 confirmed tornadoes.

Last year also experienced the longest tornado season on record, lasting 240 days, with the first tornado reported in Malden Centre, Ont. on March 16 and the last one in Fergus, Ont. on Nov. 10.

The first tornado of 2025 reportedly occurred on April 12 in Rolling Hills, Alta.

Historical tornado data in Canada

Over the last few years, NTP confirmed the following number of tornadoes across Canada:

2024 - 1292023 - 902022 - 1312021 - 1272020 - 1102019 - 802018 - 1042017 - 71

Based on a 30-year period between 1991 and 2020, the average number of tornadoes per year is 64.9 in Canada and 18.5 in Ontario, Sillis said.

The NTP team is investigating why some years are less active, in terms of tornadoes, than others, with Sillis saying there are many factors involved.

Possible reasons for fewer tornadoes this season

Environment Canada couldn't provide a definitive answer as to why we're experiencing fewer tornadoes this year, but offered a hypothesis.

Meteorologist Steven Flisfeder said there are two possible causes why Ontario, and particularly southern Ontario, are experiencing fewer tornadoes this year.

One is that this summer has been dominated by high-pressure systems, which are typically associated with clear skies.

"That would have the tendency to inhibit any kind of storms, any kind of convection, which would lead to lightning, which would lead to potential thunderstorms, which would lead to potential tornadoes," Flisfeder said.

"That high pressure, which was very strong, very persistent throughout the summer, is a possible reason why there were fewer tornadoes than we normally see in a typical year."

The second possibility is related to all the forest fire smoke we've experienced this year, particularly in June and July.

"There was a lot of smoke in the atmosphere, which has a tendency to reduce solar heating, which would help reduce the potential for thunderstorm initiation as well," Flisfeder said.

This is just a hypothesis, he added, noting a definitive answer would require further research.

Is tornado season over yet? Expert outlook

Sillis expects the number of confirmed tornadoes to climb before the year is out.

The NTP team is still reviewing satellite images from Canada's vast boreal forest, which could turn up more tornadoes from this summer that had not been reported yet due to the area's low population density.

"So, the numbers from this summer will likely go up," he said, and tornado season is likely not over yet.

"I suspect we haven't seen the end of the tornado season in Ontario, or Canada, quite yet. In fact, we've got quite a warm-up in the long-range forecast for southern Ontario, and that typically means higher potential for severe storms," he added.

More information on tornadoes in Canada is available on the NTP website.

Link to Story

Discover the Enchanting, Eco-Conscious Epic That's Captivating Readers Young and OldIn the dappled light of an ancient forest, where the air hums with life and the earth smells of damp leaves and possibility, a secret civilization has thrived in harmony with nature since the days of cavemen. They are the Crum, a remarkable offshoot of hominidae, standing no taller than thirteen inches, with leaf-green hair, grey-brown skin, and the extraordinary ability to hear the thoughts of the animals they live among. This is the breathtaking world introduced in the new novel, Roo and the World of Crum.


This is not a story of conquest, but of connection. It is a ground-level epic that unfolds in the mossy undergrowth, along babbling creeks, and under the roots of mighty oaks. Readers are invited to don a "shum" (a camouflaging cowl) and step into the shoes of Roo, a young and curious Crum, and his fox companion, Fen. Together, they navigate the wonders and perils of the forest-from forging friendships with a wise old stag and a mischievous raccoon to confronting the terrifying, indiscriminate danger of a forest fire.
Roo and the World of Crum is a masterfully woven tapestry of adventure, heart, and profound respect for the natural world. The story delves deep into the Crum's sustainable way of life: their burrows illuminated by cultivated phosphorescent mushrooms, their leather clothes crafted from respectfully sourced materials, and their solemn rituals that return their departed to the earth under the roots of trees. It's a poignant reminder of our place within the ecosystem, teaching lessons of coexistence, bravery, and compassion without ever feeling like a lesson.
The narrative pulses with the life of the forest floor. You'll feel the smooth gait of a fox beneath you, smell the sweet decay of autumn leaves, and hear the simple, earnest thoughts of the creatures who call the woods home. This is a book that doesn't just tell a story; it immerses you in an ecosystem.
Roo and the World of Crum is more than a book; it's an experience. It's a call to listen more closely to the world around us, to tread a little lighter, and to find magic in the most unexpected places.
Roo and the World of Crumis available for purchase in paperback and eBook formats on Amazon.
About the Author
Carrie A. Keller, an artist, instructor, and illustrator from Ontario, Canada, poured her creative energy into crafting the whimsical yet profound world of the Crum. Her background in art infuses every detail of the story, offering readers not just an adventure but an aesthetic and emotional journey. Keller's ability to weave imagination with environmental awareness ensures that Roo and the World of Crum remains a cherished book for readers young and old.

Author's Tranquility Press is committed to showcasing stories that endure across time and generations. With Roo and the World of Crum, the press continues its mission to bring forward works that captivate the imagination while carrying meaningful messages for today's world.

The community members point out that the situation is critical and that, with the imminent arrival of new rains, the risk of further flooding increases.
Therefore, they demand the immediate execution of drainage works and technical solutions to control the reservoir of the Tragadero lagoon, whose accumulation of water threatens more towns in the valley.

In view of the critical situation, the National Water Authority (ANA) presented the Regional Government of Junín and the Regional Agrarian Management Committee with a technical action plan to mitigate the risk of flooding in the Tragadero lagoon, which currently stores more than nine million cubic meters of water, a volume much higher than usual levels.
Immediate measures include the controlled evacuation of excess water and the cleaning of the Millpún drain, actions that would reduce the level of the lagoon and facilitate the draining of the water. In the medium term, the plan calls for the preparation of a bathymetric study, the installation of flow and level monitoring systems, and a comprehensive diagnosis of the Yanamarca river basin in order to design storage works to mitigate future floods during the rainy season.
Likewise, the feasibility of investment projects to divert excess flows to other basins will be evaluated, and work will be done to delimit the marginal strip in coordination with local governments, guaranteeing greater safety for the communities settled in the area.

Road situation
Ten secondary roads remain cut this Friday by forest fires, seven in several provinces of Castilla y León, two in Galicia and one in Extremadura, according to the latest information updated by the Directorate General of Traffic (DGT).
Most of them are in the province of León, where circulation is still prohibited in both directions on the LE-2703, between Portilla de la Reina and Santa Marina de Valdeón; the LE-4212, between Cariseda and Chano; the LE-5228, between Bouzas and Corporales; and the LE-7311, between Nogar and Castrillo de Cabrera.
In Zamora, the ZA-103 and ZA-104, in Sanabria, and in Palencia, the P-217 in Cardaño de Abajo, all of them also in both directions, are closed.
The two roads closed to traffic, in both directions, in Galicia are the PO-552, between As Mariñas and Mouga, and the LU-P-1801, in Arxemil.
In Extremadura, the CC-224, which connects the Cáceres valleys of Ambroz and Jerte between Hervás and Cabezuela del Valle via the Honduras pass, continues to be closed in the increasing direction of the kilometer.
